metadata.title: Dudh Sukto | দুধ শুক্তো | Bengali Recipies
metadata.description:
Dudh Shukto by Ipsita Laha Konar I রুরাল রেসিপির দশম পর্ব । পূর্ব বর্ধমানের বননবগ্রামের বাসিন্দা শ্রীমতি ঈপ্সিতা লাহা কোনারের হাতের রান্না :   দুধ শুক্তো ।

Shukto holds a timeless position as a staple delicacy in Bengali cuisine, often served at the onset of a meal.   While its slightly bitter taste may deter some, its health benefits, particularly during the summer, are widely acknowledged. This traditional dish features an array of vegetables, with bitter gourd or neem leaves taking center stage. Originally prepared by frying vegetables with spices and asafoetida, the recipe has evolved over time to include milk and poppy seeds, enriching its flavor profile.

Rural local recipes are integral part of Intangible Cultural Heritage and needs to be preserved and promoted. We at banglanatak dot com have been working for the past 22+ years to safeguard and promote local cultural heritages in rural spaces across India. We are now launching a new initiative of documenting rural recipes and bringing them closer to the food lovers of the world.   We request all to subscribe to our new channel Rural Recipes and stay tuned there to know, learn and try out local delicacies.

transcription_english: [00:00:09] Hello, today we have come to another friend’s house—Ipsita, Ipsita Laha Konar.
[00:00:22] Ipsita Laha Konar is someone I met/connected with for the first time (my first introduction).
[00:00:25] Today she is going to cook a very common dish, but a wonderful dish for summer.
[00:00:32] It is called Dudh Shukto (Milk Shukto). Ipsita is going to cook Dudh Shukto today.
[00:00:36] While talking with Ipsita, I learned something new.
[00:00:41] There is another name for radhuni, a very important ingredient in shukto.
[00:00:46] Ipsita knows another name for radhuni—what is it? Chandani.
[00:00:50] Chandani. Why is it called Chandani?
[00:00:52] Because it has a different flavor.
[00:00:55] I have taken oil.
[00:01:07] Mustard oil.
[00:01:10] First, fry the bori (lentil dumplings).
[00:01:11] If the oil is too hot and the bori turns black, it won’t taste good.
[00:01:16] Fry the bori.
[00:01:16] We will fry it for 5–10 minutes.
[00:01:19] After that we will take the bori out.
[00:01:22] Don’t fry it for too long,
[00:01:23] otherwise it will break.
[00:01:24] Fry it for at least 5 minutes.
[00:01:44] Let me sing a song.
[00:01:55] (Song line) My dear, my dear…
[00:01:58] (Song line) Look at the night…
[00:02:00] (Song line) It is so beautiful…
[00:02:02] (Song line) My dear, my dear…
[00:02:03] (Song line) The night is so beautiful…
[00:02:08] (Song line) My dear, my dear…
[00:02:11] (Song line) Look at the night…
[00:02:17] (Song line) Look at the night…
[00:02:23] Now we will fry the potatoes.
[00:02:44] I added radhuni/chandani, poppy seeds, black mustard seeds, bay leaves, ghee, salt, sugar, and milk.
[00:03:50] Now I am going to add green chilies and red chilies…
[00:04:39] [Cooking continues with green chilies]
[00:05:07] [Cooking continues]
